content.body: Chrome has rolled in a preliminary WebForms validity API that has broken my site
i'm going to report it as a bug, but i want to make sure i'm correct before i do
if a radio or checkbox group has an element checked, the whole control should be valid, shouldn't it
where "whole control" means every input with the same name
afa: you're using the "required" attribute?
yeah
I'm checking what the spec says
if it's not an implementation bug then it's clearly a spec bug
thanks
afa: for checkboxes, the spec says it is based on just the element's checkedness
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#checkbox-state
So I guess a "required" checkbox has to be checked, regardless of the group
afa: for radiobuttons, it is supposed to be per group
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#radio-button-state
afa: according to that spec, if any radiobutton in the group has checkedness of true, validation should pass
sorry for wandering off
that link crashes opera (and my IRC session)
so anything you said after that, i didnt get
afa: eek, sorry
it's been a while since i worked on this app, so i want to make sure my memory is correct
if you POST a checkbox, then multiple identical keys get sent for each checked checkbox with the same name, correct?
so if c1s1q1 had values 0 and 1 checked,
afa: short version, for checkbox, "required" requires each checkbox to be chacked, regardless of "name", for radio buttons, it's per group
c1s1q1=0&c1s1q1=1 would be POSTed?
I think that's right but I don't really know
i know when i first brought this up, you said this may be a spec bug
and i know that the unintuitive parts of HTML are often there for a reason (perhaps legacy cruft, perhaps others)
if it was true for radio buttons, yeah
so i want to discuss this before i comment on the RFC
@required isn't legacy
i know, but i know in other cases, there have been reasons for the unintuitive parts
so i want to make sure this isnt the case :)
I think for radio buttons it works as you expect, for checkboxes, what the spec says sounds reasonable to me
the radio bug is a problem in chrome
the checkbox is a conflict between my JS implementation and the docs
i may comment on that part of the spec just to get feedback
on its face, it's not wholly unreasonable
but it seems to me that a group validation is more flexible and consistent
so any multiple choice widget, whether mutually exclusive or not, has the same API
if you want to require a box to be checked, put it in its own group
i submitted a comment on the checkbox validity API:
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9160
i'd love to hear other's input

It is amazing to see Microsoft's reaction to the serious threat that HTML5 has to the OS centric market place after the acquisition of On2. The tactic of using a hobbled Internet explorer to hold back Internet centric applications is finally about to fail and they know it. That's what this is all about. The Microsoft dinosaur is thrashing around in it's tar pit. Microsoft has a lot of fellow reptiles in this tar pit , so I hope we get HTM
The reptiles will continue to mass. Microsoft , Adobe, Xerox and anyone else whose lock is about to be picked
Rupert Murdoch is worried about his lunch too

Sports fans the clock is ticking. If HTML5 with CODEC  makes it out there in the next few months the battle is won. If the process of integration and distribution languishes in vacillations , there are indeed enough dinosaurs out there , that when arrayed can sap even the might of Google and HTML5.  I might seem to be the ranting member of the tin hat squad, but multi national businesses are real. Their interests in various media locks ar
What was a simple quest to improve an Internet standard , has wide ranging consequences , perhaps wider ranging than many have realized.

It's no longer just the university soda machine or a novelty toaster , but your TV , Fridge , car , telephone , very aspect of your life.  That is a lot of money, and attracts the attention of a lot of very powerful people.  HTML5 along with it's video component represents a major threat to the alternatives to same in every field mentioned and mant more. We are speaking of trillions of trillions of dollars, all over what seems a tiny litt
Attacking big firms like Google has status , and properly crafted FUD and FNORDS will allow the leveraging of the dinosaurs to achieve the goals of political maggots everywhere.
I hope that someone will step up and calm my fears with rational discourse that lets me know that my fears are simply un-founded.
Will of th e104 people here , even one stand up and make the case that this is not a real issue?
Not even one of the 104 people here feel it worth saying I'm wrong , that the current attack on Google is really a fear of HTML5
or, it's late friday evening/early saturday morning for everyone
It would be a false assumption to consider lack of comment agreement , so I ask it the other way,
does anyone here feel that recent actions by Microsoft, Xerox,Adobe and other firms via litigation , government manipulation
and other methods might be born of fears that an Internet Applications Platform might threaten their business models?
so party, on.
Not sure if that comment was towards me or not , but if it were , I would consider same to be in the context of
of a virtual multi-alarm fire and th idea that we should but party on , not be a valid answer to the fire
I've been programming since before the first PC , and certainly before Microsoft appeared on the scene. I've experienced
first hand many pivotal points  in technology. One can research my comments throughout the history of the Internet and
if they have access to RYBBS and FIDO net historical data my pre-Internet expressions when communications were limited
to at my beginnings 150 bits/sec. I'm not often wrong nor do I often make this loud a noise

Come on folks , either agree that HTML5 is a threat to the powers that be and that the current responses of Adobe, Microsoft , Xerox and indirectly Rupert Murdoch and other powers are a serious threat , or call me out as the fool. Or at least say something. This is a real issue IMHO and should be seen as a call to action. If you consider it to be a yawn fest , say so.
HTML5 is a major seed change in the way businesses address applications development. Those changes have a major effect on
the bottom lines of trillions of dollars in business. Everyone just too focused on a weekend of party hardy?  People think that Google my favorite champion is bullet proof? What is it?
AOL and Compuserve were considered by many pendents at the time to be bullet proof.

IMHO Microsoft is a POS , but in this case it is not simply Uncle Bill , nor even computer or Internet centric businesses that have skin in the game. This means that folks you have never even heard of that have significant market power  are taking aim.

I have on multiple occasions suggested that Google implement a search engine that harvests sec.gov and similar global representations of corporate family trees to allow folks to see who owns who and to understand in an easy way the behaviors of various corporate and news entities. A single link to a child's mobile of relationships would prove my point
Having to dig about to know that Rupert Murdoch owns MySpace.com and has significant interests in Hulu.com
should not be a thing I need to prove by elaborate means
To show the interactions between Rupert Murdoch and Microsoft , Direct TV , NBC and such is not something I should need to prove
Simply citing a google link would make this easy
Should I need to prove
1.) Microsoft ownes "Ciao" a German search site. A complainant in the EU anti rust case against Google
2.) "Foundem" member of Microsoft funded ICOMP (Initiative for a Competitive Marketplace)
Should I need to prove the other links from Microsoft to the each and every issue at hand
HTML5 and the CODEC VP8 need to resolve themselves in weeks not months
Should I need to re-prove the findings of governments around the world regarding Microsoft?
HTML5 is indeed the future of  the Internet, but don't be so arrogant as to believe that life fixes itself
that good by itself defeats evil. Internet standards are a stdrong position
But a camp fire no matter how well made , left undefended is defeated by but a small amount of even polluted water
OK , the audience went from 104 to 102 IRC viewers. Stop jacking off at porn and say something, or do you want to pay evil companies for your right to even make a living?
Silence is your support of behaviors of companies like Microsoft,Adobe, Xerox and others and your desire to be their slaves.
If your of little concern for your own worth , I'm sure we can fasten your mouth to a hole in a bathroom stall
Come on kids , this is not a Google or Microsoft sanctioned discussion room.
"Ian Hicks" will not care if we say some word of disconcerting nature.
Do you not have an opinion? This does indeed effect your livelihood.
Tell me I'm full of shit , I dare ya. Do I need to get a Microsoft fanboy in the room to gets some discussion?
Is everyone that chicken shit or ignorant to how this effects their life to care?
Fine , than all of you who will in over 100 people not take a position deserve what ya git, but
I for one will be looking in each and every breath to how the peoples Internet , paid for by them  can continue to be fore them

and will in the event that the evils are set upon their heels cite the 103 people here as those who left it to others to make sure that the Internet is as relates to standards owned and controlled by the people  and not the fab boy and moneyed personality of the moment (infrared laser scanners and other tools resumed and first occurring and detected , deflected)
Two hours wasted here  , but perhaps not. I checked to see if folk could drop their pudd  and gained that valuable
answer

the initial page load is fine, but navigating to different pages slowly makes the fonts smaller and smaller
very strange bug
easily reproducible, i hope
email me if you need further details
... What the fuck was drclue *smoking*?

I have been told via official venues that HTML5 is a religious / activist venue basically around the globe. and that in further questioning   that  the platform is covered by various terrorist directives
TabAtkins: you woke it up!
we have official venues?
OH GOD I DID IT I'M SO SORRY MACIEJ
btw anything important in my e-mail? i haven't had time to look yet and i'm probably not going to until tomorrow, so if there is, let me know :-)
I blame the CSS in my IRC.  I make joins/quits almost invisible so I can normally ignore them.
Not just some middle east thing , but any venue violating dividends with no data to support some other perception
On the other hand, now I get to enjoy a nice word salad, I guess.
Fuck all this , if nobody can challenge or even agree I I'm out of here as I have far more worthy folks to give the word
Have fun, drclue.
So, in other news, *finally* got my damned diploma in the mail today.
Geeze [TabAtkins[ actually says even something, and at last gets some warm thoughts from me
Hixie: we sent the TransReqs for our FPWDs
Not sure what to think vs mail and stale
Hixie: will send pubreq once those are approved
othermaciej: k
TabAtkins: grats re diploma
If hixie wants to say something , gold , anyone wants to claim Hixie fuck ya
Hixie: also Tim officially said HTML5 is in scope for HTML5
(dunno if you were around for that one)
Hixie is not particularly god , but of less mind to be a pain than those making noise
Look , Microsoft is dying unless they can trash us , so what ya got to say?
So really  , I need to on my own shoulders Internet freedom from a word
I feel like quoting TabAtkins, but I'd probably just wake up the dragon again
(Not that it matters, since I'm going to sleep now, myself.)
Hixie, maybe we should just push for another port again?
with web sockets
JonathanNeal: Your while loops look wrong
while (--i) only loops i-1 times
You should write normal for loops rather than trying to be clever with micro-optimisations that will make no practical difference :-)
would like to complain about the snow
Why?
Snow is vastly superior to ice and sludge
Because yesterday it was raining and washing the snow away. Today it is snowing again
You should complain about the rain then :)
It's too early for spring yet
So there will be more ice and sludge in the future compared to it raning again and wasking more snow away
You should complain about the ground - if there wasn't any then the snow couldn't build up
I expect such a complaint would be dismissed as groundless
(sorry)
Someone mentioned http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2010/02/ogg-theora-vs-h264-head-to-head-comparisons.ars here recently

A relevant comment from http://x264dev.multimedia.cx/?p=292#comment-2768 : "We talked about that on IRC, both with x264 and Theora people: all considered it one of the worst articles they had ever seen."
So probably best not to pay too much attention to it
Hmm
Chrome thinks my test page full of "ABCD" is written in Danish and offers to translate it
>it should explicitly say alt="" MUST NOT be blank unless it MAY be left blank
Isn't that implied? Or am I misunderstanding how the terms work
Implied requirements are dangerous
It seems generally better to be explicit
doesn't like "x MAY y if z" because he's never quite sure if the intention was "x MUST NOT y if not z", or "x MUST NOT (not y) if z", or something else
although in the case of <area> it already says it must be text that's somehow equivalent to the image area, so I don't see why it'd need to be stated again
For additional fun, write requirements on the form "x MAY not y"
And "x MUST only y if z"
and "x MUST y only if z"
Maybe all normative criteria should be written using some kind of formal logic notation
RFC2119 is fine as long as you use the words in simple sentences ("if z, then y MUST x", "if not z, then y MUST NOT x", etc)
and I think HTML5 generally does that quite consistently now
Oddly, Opera kerns text with strokeText on Linux but not with fillText
and with neither on Windows

In your ThinkPad?

Is there a reliable way to make sure a @font-face is loaded before trying to draw with it?
Firefox and Opera seem to block onload as long as the font is used in a (non-display:none) element within the page itself, so that's okay
Chromium doesn't, so it randomly works only half the time
and if I do something like draw with the font, then wait a bit to make sure it's really loaded and draw again, Chromium crashes
so that's not so good
and I'm not sure how else to do it
Oh, seems to work better if I actually use characters from the font in the page
Philip`: Detect the character width?
gsnedders: That would only help detect whether the font has been loaded, and wouldn't cause it to become loaded
Philip`: position: absolute; visibility: hidden; top: 0; left: 0; I guess would cause it to load
Philip`: Without interfering with anything
That seems to work
(I was doing opacity:0 which also seems to work)
with a 0.5s delay before drawing to make sure it's really loaded
because WebKit doesn't delay onload, it seems
Opera doesn't even get textAlign correct :-(
Current canvas text-drawing test scores:
Opera is trailing with 52%
Chromium is a bit better at 56%
Firefox is racing into the lead with a staggering 61%
Awesome performance by Firefox
gets bored and decides he has enough tests for now
Reminds me of a survey done here in Norway recently, which asked which dialect was the sexiest, and proclaimed that the northern areas were the winner.
Now, the northern area dialect had got a whooping 12% of the votes
And the least popular one had 7%
Philip`, are you uploading the new version of the test suite?
annevk: I will do once I've fixed some other broken tests
http://philip.html5.org/tests/canvas/suite/tests/results.html
can't be bothered to run them all on Windows too
It's possible some tests are buggy - if anyone notices any, please let me know
(Also there's some things I haven't tested at all yet, like <video>)
annevk: ^
(Also, actual tests at http://philip.html5.org/tests/canvas/suite/tests/)
(Maybe the results page should link back there...)
Hello all!
JonathanNeal: Hello, and http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20100227#l-282
Philip`, I don't quite follow.
Philip`, oh, so Opera has the highest score rather than the lowest
seems like a lot of trivial bugs we ought to fix
Oh I see it.
annevk: Highest if you count all of the tests, and weight them all equally
(and if I don't have serious bugs in my test runner)
Most are trivial and boring, though there's some like http://philip.html5.org/tests/canvas/suite/tests/index.2d.text.draw.baseline.html where it might be nice if top/bottom/middle worked properly
Philip`: Maybe this is the kind of stuff Larry was talking about as overspecifying
Non-existence of createImageData is maybe the biggest thing
Dashiva: Maybe, but they're almost all things that could come up in practice
I'd probably call it "sensible, unambiguous, testable level of specification" rather than "overspecification"
I agree personally, but minor bugs that don't get fixed even over time may suggest otherwise

Dashiva: It may suggest that expecting implementations to have 100% conformance is unrealistic and not a good use of anybody's time (and so the Rec criteria are broken and harmful), but problems are much more likely to get fixed if they're clearly specified and tested than if they're not
so I don't think it suggests that it's not good to specify all the behaviour
